Class SchemaSwingView

java.lang.Object
edu.rit.g2.view.SchemaView
edu.rit.g2.view.SchemaSwingView
public class SchemaSwingView extends SchemaView
A Swing-based implementation of the SchemaView abstraction.

This view is responsible for presenting SQL output, status messages, and error notifications to the user through standard Swing UI components. It directly updates a JTextArea for SQL display and a JLabel for status reporting, making it suitable for desktop-based interaction.

This class does not contain business logic. Instead, it strictly follows MVC principles by displaying information passed from the controller through SchemaView's abstract methods.

Responsibilities:

  • Show success messages in green
  • Show error messages in red and in a popup dialog
  • Display generated SQL in a non-editable text area
  • Provide feedback on file save locations
Since:
1.0
Version:
1.0
Author:
Acer

      Constructs a Swing-based view with UI components dedicated for SQL display and status messaging.

      public void showSuccess(String message)
      Displays a success message to the user.

      Success text is colored green for positive visual feedback.

      Overrides:

      Parameters:

    • showError

      public void showError(String message)
      Displays an error message to the user.

      Error text is colored red and additionally shown in a Swing dialog.

      Overrides:
      showError in class SchemaView
      Parameters:

    • showSql

      public void showSql(String sql)
      Displays the generated SQL output.

      The caret is reset to the start of the text to ensure the user sees the beginning of the SQL output.

      Overrides:
      showSql in class SchemaView
      Parameters:
      sql - the SQL string to display; if null, the area is cleared

    • savedTo

      public void savedTo(String path)
      Displays a message informing the user where the generated SQL was saved.
      Overrides:
      savedTo in class SchemaView
      Parameters:
      path - the filesystem path where SQL was written
